title: Was Albert Einstein correct when he called Sir Isaac Newton the smartest person who ever lived? - Quora

response.answer_text: citation needed… I am unable to find any reference where Einstein writes that Isaac Newton was the smartest person who ever lived, although he did write glowingly of Newton sometimes. “Fortunate Newton, happy childhood of science! … In one person he combined the experimenter, the theorist, the mechanic—and, not least, the artist in exposition. He stands before us strong, certain, and alone: his joy in creation and his minute precision are evident in every word and in every figure. “— Einstein A.* Whoever said it… the correctness depends on the context. Newton was certainly a particularly tall Giant in achievements towards the understanding of the Natural World. Does that make him the smartest person ever? I don’t know: what standard are you using to measure smartness?  [*] Describing the reader’s experience while perusing the Opticks. From Isaac Newton, Opticks, Or, A Treatise of the Reflections, Refractions, Inflections (1730; Dover edition, 1979), Forward by Albert Einstein, lix.

response.answer_text: Was Albert Einstein correct when he called Sir Isaac Newton the smartest person who ever lived? Yes, that appears to be true. Biography for Kids: Scientist - Isaac Newtonhttps://www.ducksters.com/biography/scientists/isaac_newton.php Even Albert Einstein said that Isaac Newton was the smartest person that ever lived. During his lifetime Newton developed the theory of gravity, the laws of motion (which became the basis for physics), a new type of mathematics called calculus, and made breakthroughs in the area of optics such as the reflecting telescope.
